body: Not sure how I feel about that, you can access the formatters from the configuration object, it might be better to use that instead?
It's unclear to me why you need to use that class...can you explain your use case?  If it's best to make that class public we can do that but I want to understand what you're trying to do first :).

guard-rspec needs to define a custom formatter (`-r .*/lib/guard/rspec/formatter.rb -f Guard::RSpec::Formatter`) so to avoiding to overwrite formatters already configured (by the user) we need to access the configuration options and keep existing formatters.

ie, if `RSpec::Core::ConfigurationOptions#options[:formatters]` returns `['doc','output']` we generate command like:

`-f doc -o output -r .*/lib/guard/rspec/formatter.rb -f Guard::RSpec::Formatter`

if nothing is set:

`-f progress -r .*/lib/guard/rspec/formatter.rb -f Guard::RSpec::Formatter`

Does it make any sense?

Formatters can be set directly on `RSpec.configuration` as well, and those won't be exposed by `RSpec::Core::ConfigurationOptions`.  Is there any reason `RSpec.configuration.formatters` doesn't meat your needs?
`RSpec.configuration.formatters` returns the formatters object, so I'm not sure what is the best way to get formatter name and output from there (i.e. to have `-f doc -o output` at the end).

It's a collection of formatters, manually creates yours programmatically and add it into the collection. That way you don't have to overwrite existing formatters and you don't have to parse options...
Note, you can do this through the configuration object itself, `config.add_formatter MyCustomClass, my_custom_output`
Yeah, but Guard::RSpec doesn't touch any user config file, it build the command on the fly and run it with `Kernel.system`. So I'm even not sure that adding formatters programmatically will work.
In that case why do you even need to parse the command line string?

Because guard-rspec user can provide a custom command, to add their own stuff. Like:

```
guard :rspec, cmd: 'spring rspec -f doc' do
  # ...
end
```

and we still need to add our custom formatter after.

More info here: https://github.com/guard/guard-rspec#options
So simply append `-f custom_formatter -o output` to the string, a quick test suggests that works just fine without parsing...

@JonRowe after some more testing, just appending `-f custom_formatter -o output` didn't work if user has its configuration inside a `.rspec` file (same issue if I use the noted as non-public `config.add_formatter`, I guess). Formatter set in `.rspec` is overwritten.

So if I want to add a formatter without overwriting the existing one, I need to access them before. Or it is maybe something fixable on rspec-core side?

With my recent changes in #1454 and #1455, we need to make `ConfigurationOptions` public and it's at a point where I'm more comfortable doing so.  I'm working on a PR to do that.

As for @thibaudgg question about adding a formatter without overwriting an existing one...@JonRowe, can you answer that since you've been doing formatter stuff?

You should be able to add two formatters in `.rspec` same as you can add two formatters on the command line. However I don't think one formatter in `.rspec` and one on the command line will combine, as we expect command line to take precedence over `.rspec` options.

You should still be able to add a second formatter programmatically regardless of original configuration method.

issue.title: Make configuration options public
issue.body:
This closes #1355. I also cleaned up some doc issues I noticed and cleaned up the DRb code a bit (including getting the last pending spec to pass!).
